description.narrative: The objective of the intervention is to mitigate the risks of fraud, corruption and sexual harassment, exploitation and abuse or breaches of organiationational codes of conduct by INGO and NGO staff and partners in Uganda, including local partner organisations, vendors, contractors and volunteers.

The Internal Risk Management Group (IRMG) in Uganda, currently consisting of 51 International Non-Government Ogranisations (INGO), has, through Mercy Corps Europe as agreement partner, applied to Sida for funding of 5 million SEK to carry out the "Internal Risk Management Group (IRMG), Uganda" in Uganda during a period of 14 months with a preliminary start date of 1 June 2020.
The intervention aims at increasing the safety of INGO program participants and improve the overall impact, accountability and effectiveness of INGO programs in Uganda by
1) Improve organizational culture concerning dealing with fraud and corruption
2) Improve the safeguarding practices of INGOs and reduce the risks of SHEA and child abuse in NGO programs and
3) Leverage lessons learned and knowledge of the IRMG to benefit the wider civil society sector in Uganda to improve on managing wrongful conduct, including safeguarding practices and the prevention of fraud and corruption.
Mercy Corps and the IRMG will implement the intervention together with the local Civil Society Organisations in Uganda.
The intervention’s total budget is 5 million SEK of which the majority of the funds will be transferred to Mercy Corps Uganda, where the contribution will be implemented. The agreement holder will however be Mercy Corps Europe.

“Internal Risk Management Group” (IRMG) i Uganda, som för närvarande består av 51 internationella icke-statliga organisationer (Non Government Organisations), har genom ”Mercy Corps Europe” som avtalspartner, ansökt om finansiering om 5 miljoner SEK för att implementera programmet "Internal Risk Management Group (IRMG), Uganda" under en period om 14 månader med preliminärt startdatum 1 juni 2020.
Insatsen syftar till att påverka och förbättra ansvarsutkrävande och effektivitet i INGO medlemmars program genom att:
1) Stärka organisationskultur med syfte att förebygga och motverka bedrägeri och korruption.
2) Stärka skyddsmekanismer och processer hos INGO medlemmar och hantera risker för sexuella trakasserier, utnyttjande och missbruk.
3) Dra på lärdomar och kunskap från IRMG medlemmar till fördel för civilsamhällssektorn i Uganda för att förbättra hantering av oegentligheter, inklusive alla former av kränkningar samt för att motverka bedrägeri och korruption.
Mercy Corps och IRMG kommer att implementera insatsen tillsammans med lokala civilsamhällsorganisationer i Uganda.
Insatsens totala budget är 5 miljoner SEK varav merparten kommer att användas av Mercy Corps i Uganda där insatsen implementeras. Avtalspart är Mercy Corps Europe.

description.narrative:
Some results reported;
- Due to covid-19-restrictions, training had to transfer to a mainly virtual mode. However, this was not supported by enrolled participants; a survey carried out by the project team revealed that less than 10% of the enrolled participants were interested in a virtual learning environment as opposed to the interactive face-to-face approach. Because of this, training activities were temporarily postponed until face-to-face meeting were possible. Trainings resumed mid-August 2021.
- Successfully completed the Phase 2 Safeguarding Training The target was 200 participants, mainly staff from member organisations (100 from INGOs and 100 from LNGOs) in three locations (Kampala, Arua and Moroto). The training aimed at building the capacity of both staff members (program, administrative and field staff) as well as the senior management team. In the end, a total of 210 Participants (149 in Kampala, 43 in Arua and 18 in Moroto) from 38 Member Organisations and 16 Non-Member Organisations were trained from mid-August September 2021.
Additionally, the safeguarding training also targeted building capacity of leadership teams (mainly directors) as well as the donor community from 23 entities.
- Safeguarding Case Management/Co-Investigations Training Targeting at least 100 participants from the 68 member organisations, at least 45 in Kampala, 30 in Arua and 25 members in Moroto.
- Outreach to partners and CSOs that work with IRMG member organisations to take part in the training exercise.
- Fund-raising for Phase 3 by IRMG Steering Committee Members. Not only identifying potential funders for Phase 3 but also establishing mechanisms by which the project could be sustainable in itself, should there be challenges in getting external funders on board.
The completion rate of the program during the period was 75%, which is deemed good as a lot of trainings and other activities were on hold due to the lock-down in summer months and the general meeting restrictions.
